instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message:
I changed the screen on my customers iMac retina 27". And now after the swap, the fans start to goes super high.

Does anyone know why or what the problem could be?

1. i have tried resetting PRAM. NVRAM. Still same problem.

thanks for your feedback. Attached is an image.

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message: Sensor failure, i guess is LCD temp sensor, hold "D" key after chime and see if any error pops up..

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message: There is a temp sensor on the back of the LCD, transfer it over from the cracked one.

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 37917"]There is a temp sensor on the back of the LCD, transfer it over from the cracked one.[/QUOTE]

 I changed the temp sensor cable, from the old one to the new lCD screen.. The FAN still running high.. What now?

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 37878"]Sensor failure, i guess is LCD temp sensor, hold "D" key after chime and see if any error pops up..[/QUOTE]

I Hold "D" button for sometime right after chime. but only white screen shows up.. and nothing else. The fan still going HIGH.. What now?

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message: Put back old LCD and see if problem goes away. Also inspect LCD cable for damage.

threads.title: [SOLVED]iMac Retina 27" - Fan goes high and air in the back of computer!
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 37987"]Put back old LCD and see if problem goes away. Also inspect LCD cable for damage.[/QUOTE]

Thanks Duke.. U where the right.. It was the heat cable for LCD screen that was missing. I didnt see it or think of it when i changed the screen.. It was the smaller cable.. Now everything is working perfect.. :)

Thanks guys, best support forum there is anywhere in the world from what I know of. You guys rock.
